> Patch Set 7:
> 
> Thanks Brian for the review.
> 
> > Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > This definitely makes sense for update (which is also create).  But for show and delete, suppose that an operator's workflow for deleting a user from their cloud is: (1) remove them from keystone so they aren't authorized to do anything anymore, and then (2) go to each service and remove quotas.  The operator won't be able to see if there are any quotas for that project and won't be able to delete them if there are.  So these would just accumulate in the database, which doesn't seem to be ideal.
> 
> The delete problem is fixed by the followup patch[1] which can remove quota records with invalid project id (removed recently or exists before this change). I separated both patches because of a pep8 failure which is blocking this patch for a long time, this change is important without that too so hence split it up.
> The problem with the show command is it shows records for non-existent project ids which is really confusing. It is a double ended problem but i feel it's better to not show information rather than showing wrong information. Also if an operator removes a project from keystone, they don't need to show it and can directly remove its quota records via the cinder-manage command added in the followup patch.
> 
> [1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/801048/

I think I prefer either leaving the backward compatible option of allowing deletion of non existing projects (consider it an idempotent operation).
We could also make it more complicated, though I don't think it's worth it:
If there are quota records we clean them regardless, if there aren't we fail if the project doesn't exist.
Or we could even add a microversion so the check on delete only happens on the new microversion.

> Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1
> 
> This definitely makes sense for update (which is also create).  But for show and delete, suppose that an operator's workflow for deleting a user from their cloud is: (1) remove them from keystone so they aren't authorized to do anything anymore, and then (2) go to each service and remove quotas.  The operator won't be able to see if there are any quotas for that project and won't be able to delete them if there are.  So these would just accumulate in the database, which doesn't seem to be ideal.

I agree with most of what you say, but I think we should only remove the check on the delete operation, because leaving it in the show or update makes no practical sense; after all there is no way to know using cinder api's if the returned values are coming from the global quota limit defaults or the per project overrides, which is one of the reasons why people go crazy, because you ask cinder to show you the quota for FAKEPROJECT and it will return valid values to you, even if there are no records for it in the database.

cinder/api/contrib/quotas.py.message: -1: We could have "garbage" records in the DB, so we need some way to delete them.  One way would be to add a "cinder-manage quota" command.

cinder/cmd/manage.py.message: ?: I don't know if it's possible, but could we import cinder.quota_utils (which loads keystone_authtoken config options), set the username, password, and project_name conf options, and then use cinder.quota_utils._keystone_client method?

I tried it and it doesn't work since the the _keystone_client method doesn't take parameters from the conf section but rather gets the token from context (which in this case doesn't contain and user/project info)
Also calling the _keystone_client method uses CONF.keystone_authtoken.auth_url parameter which for some reason isn't set when called from here.

-1: This will block the whole Quota table and probably halt many Cinder operations  :-(
-1: For a single project we may have multiple Quota rows, so this code, together with the for loop will result in us querying keystone multiple times for the same project.

I think we should just get the unique project_id fields from that table, query keystone once, and then use DB's quota_destroy_all_by_project instead.

If this is running from cinder manager and cinder manager has access to the cinder.conf file, do we need to have the user specify these options?

Would a reasonable alternative be to just pull the credentials from `cinder.conf [keystone_authtoken]` and use those instead, or is there a case I'm missing?

What if you try:

  ks_loading.register_auth_conf_options(CONF, 'keystone_authtoken')

before line 572?

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/743142
Is this patch? Could you point out which function need the information of what? And what will new service plugin do with this information?

Is this line?
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/743142/15/neutron/services/ndp_proxy/plugin.py@90

The funtion _check_router_update needs to check if the router gateway updated? If yes, then the resource type is ROUTER_GATEWAY now. And it includes the request external_gateway_info in the request_body.

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/6d570dfd7dc4814b3cdb2c1b3cadaf34fb7927af#diff-fd128e4178b24eff549251e292a53c15a98403ced377f60679f1e9243499351a

Hi, Yulong.
The enable_ndp_proxy's purpose is that for support multiple method to publish IPv6 address to external. Reference [1].I agree with 1.1 and 1.2 in your opinions above. But, the 1.3 and 2 I don't agree, they do not obey the spec [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/728628/41/specs/xena/l3-router-support-ndp-proxy.rst#70

Yep, That's the patch. But just the external_gateway_info isn't enough. Consider a case: The user update external_gateway and enable_ndp_proxy at the same time in one request, process this case is difficult in current neutron. And current neutron the router's BEFORE_UPDATE event at the back of PRECOMMIT_UPDATE event this is unreasonable in my option. Moreover, I think the improved event payload will make other service plugin's development more convenient in the future.

This "enable_ndp_proxy" is the burden you insist to add, since I noticed this option in the spec [1]. So cloud we add some limitation here:
1. if there are ndp_proxies, 1)do not allow to unset external gateway; 2) do not allow to set external gateway to another external network; 3) do not allow to set enable_ndp_proxy = False.

2. only when there is no ndp_proxies, then we can set enable_ndp_proxy to False.

Then this cloud be simple here, receive the ROUTER_GATEWAY PRECOMMIT_UPDATE event [2]. And check the request, if it breaks the rule 1 and 2, return not allowed to user.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/728628/13/specs/victoria/l3-router-support-ndp-proxy.rst#64
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/6d570dfd7dc4814b3cdb2c1b3cadaf34fb7927af#diff-fd128e4178b24eff549251e292a53c15a98403ced377f60679f1e9243499351a

Can this be configured in a flavour rather than at the compute host level or as an image property.

As this type of instance relies on specific hardware with limited capacity it feels like something that should be flavour driven, allowing cloud operators to charge specifically for instances of this type.

specs/ussuri/backlog/cinder-ceph-ec-data.message:
This feels like the wrong approach to introducing erasure coding as a feature for this (or any other) charm in the OpenStack Charm set.  This directly exposes *how* cinder needs to be configured to the charm user, rather than allowing the charm user to express the requirement for an erasure coded pool along with basic configuration about K/M values and letting the charms figure out all of the details.

I also don't see any detail here about how the second data pool will be created - this should be automated as part of this work.

We've done similar work in the last cycle for PureStorage where all proposed changes are tested against a PureStorage array - nice to have the same for Arista.

My suggestion:

=============================
Add neutron-aci-plugin spec

This specification document describes the changes to existing charms and new charms required to support Neutron ACI plugin for OpenStack.

According to the OpenStack Charms release policy (https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/release-policy.html), a third party CI should be provided to allow testing of this charm

Speaking to the governance on this as I understand it, and recalling the discussion from a conference call earlier this year:

If the aim of the charm is to be in opendev/x/namespace (an unofficial/unstable project maintained primarily by the authors), and not in opendev/openstack/namespace (an official project with shared maintenance of the community and/or OpenStack Charms team), then this testing statement may be passable as transitional, as long as there is a stated plan to implement a test gate.

In either case, if the charm is not ultimately testable by the community via third-party-ci, it may not gain much activity, and it may be difficult to support based on history that I've observed.

Reference, important to read and be aware:

https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/feature-specification.html

https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/release-policy.html

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems

https://docs.openstack.org/infra/system-config/third_party.html

This is not yet addressed by the spec.  To put it a bit more concretely:

Is the intention to place the new charm projects under option 1 or 2?:

1. https://opendev.org/x/charm-* (Unofficial, no functional tests in gate or in third-party-ci).  With this approach, the charms would not be part of the OpenStack Charms release.

2. https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-* (Official project with functional tests in gate or in third-party-ci).  With this approach, the ACI charms could be part of the official OpenStack Charms release.

Please advise.  This is information is required in order to clarify the intent and the immediate path forward.

hooks/cinder_hooks.py.message:
Rather than defining the following code like this, we'll want to model after what keystone does. This is an issue of load time vs run time and we try to stay away from load time code. [1] What keystone does is it defines this code in a function that returns a dictionary, and then the decorator calls would look something like:

@restart_on_change(... ,
                   restart_functions=restart_function_map())

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/coding-guidelines.html#install-time-vs-load-time-vs-runtime-code
ah okay, i can write it in this way no problem, in my earnest to move the function into the imports, i completely overlooked this.. thanks guys

Thanks for this feedback Corey!  Much appreciated

There's a reason why i didn't do it this way, and maybe you have further insight into resolving or suggesting alternatives.

if you review the 3 defs, you can see the dependencies between them

restart_function_map():
https://github.com/openstack/charm-keystone/blob/master/hooks/keystone_utils.py#L557

restart_pid_check():
https://github.com/openstack/charm-keystone/blob/b59775018b73ce86d101d57c30836ffc30eff3cd/hooks/keystone_utils.py#L538

run_in_apache():
https://github.com/openstack/charm-keystone/blob/b59775018b73ce86d101d57c30836ffc30eff3cd/hooks/keystone_utils.py#L568


When trying to percolate up the code into charm helpers.

restart_pid_check has a dependency on 
https://github.com/openstack/charm-keystone/blob/master/charmhelpers/core/host.py

and run_in_apache has a dependency on 
https://github.com/openstack/charm-keystone/blob/master/charmhelpers/contrib/openstack/utils.py


Utils and core cannot include one another, as this creates a circular dependency. which is why i had to simply the code in this manner.

I believe it would take significant refactoring of charm helpers to avoid this issue.

@Adam, it would be good to get some more context as to why this change is needed.  It's not clear what the benefit of rendering XHTML is?

When you view a URL with the web browser, and you only render it in JSON, you do not get the links.  With XHTM, we can identify the portions of the Keystone API that violate the principal of discoverability.  With XHTML, a user will be able to interact with a Keystone server in the absence of a third party App or Horizon.  This is a rewrite of a PoC I did a long time ago to show the point.

One of the rationales for moving to Flask was that we could then take advantage of Flasks supports for additional rendering formats beyond JSON

actions/actions.py.message:
The name of this function somewhat implies that it is going to check that it is only being run on a leader unit. I think either do the check or remove the _on_leader from the name and just set a docstring to say should only be run on leader unit.

I also feel like all code that actually performs changes to rings should live in the same place and since that code was originally in swift_utils.py i think this should also go there.

sure, I can get behind the naming suggestions. 

I _CAN_ move these two methods to swift_utils -- but this method was originally here.  it doesn't do any of the ACTUAL work, just calls the method `remove_from_ring`

I'm slightly concerned over the False return value.  It does work, and the present code is very careful to explicitly check for False.

However, it may be better to raise an exception, as that'd be slightly less dangerous in case a caller were to forget to do that check, since the exception would immediately bubble up if not handled (rather than the code potentially proceeding silently).
I see at least 3 cases in the code (lines 224-226, 241-243, 280-281) where we compute the path to a builder file.  I think a helper for this (e.g. _get_builder_path(ring)) would improve readability.
This function is only used once, and is relatively simple.  In my opinion the code would read more cleanly if this were inlined.

This will append 'all' to ALL_RINGS, which is likely not what is expected.  Better to use ALL_RINGS + ['all'], or even define a second constant, VALID_RING_OPTIONS, defined as ALL_RINGS + ['all'].

(As this particular construct is used in at least 2 places, defining VALID_RING_OPTIONS is my preference.)

This returns an implicit None on its action_fail() branches.  While this works, raising an exception might be somewhat cleaner, and would then allow callers to assume the 2-item tuple return value when assigning to variables.

which comes from our environment when running the unit tests without a primary_key field. That made me guess at least some field like 'id' is required by the modules behind.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is there an associated bug report for this that includes a bit more detail?

Do you know what libvirt version provided the new functionality? Does our minimum libvirt version new enough to use this feature unconditionally?

Current nova min libvirt version:
MIN_LIBVIRT_VERSION = (6, 0, 0)
MIN_QEMU_VERSION = (4, 2, 0)

The limitation was lifted in libvirt v4.3.0 [1]. Our deployment of OpenStack, which is on top of StarlingX, uses libvirt v4.7.0, and suspending a guest already works in it, so v6.0 should be very safe.
Missed the ref link: [1] https://libvirt.org/news.html#v4-3-0-2018-05-02
Sounds good. Thanks.
hot-plug? We specifically want to plug them back in here right?

Yes, correct. What I meant is that when mediated devices support was being implemented in Nova, libvirt didn't support the hot-unplug of those, so the suspend operation would try to do that, fail and rollback the suspension [1]. Since that failure does not occur anymore, the mdevs are now unplugged on suspension, and what we're doing here is plugging them back in when resuming.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8003
supernit - This was introduced in v4.3.0 and kernel 4.10, MIN_LIBVIRT is currently v6.0.0.
This is not a supernit, we should somehow explain this in a release note.
Is there something I should do regarding this?
I wasn't aware of the release note process; just added one.

Looking at _detach_mediated_devices it's calling guest.detach_device that only calls libvirt once to detach the device and doesn't wait. What you could be seeing here is a race between that call and the managedSave that follows but AFAIK cause the managedSave call to fail?

Either way I think we really need to use nova.virt.libvirt.guest.Guest.detach_device_with_retry to detach these devices from the domain.

I have tested the detach function with a 10 second sleep after the libvirt call and the result is the same... There seems to be no race condition here. The device was still in the xml.

The detach_device_with_retry function you mentioned does not seem to exist. Maybe it was removed?

This is uncertain for me as well, but since the mdev exists in the XML at this moment but is not in the guest when it comes up, my guess is that libvirt persists the unplug somewhere and "remembers" this when recreating the domain. After the guest comes back up, the mdev is gone from the XML.

I think Lee tries to refer to nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver._detach_with_retry()

The _detach_mediated_devices only detach the device from the live domain so the device remains in the persistent domain (XML)

In general the LibvirtDriver.suspend() does not use the LibvirtDriver._detach_with_retry() with pci devices either but calling guest.detach_device() directly and also calls it a way that only detach the device from the live domain not from the persistent one.

    def resume(self, context, instance, network_info, block_device_info=None):
        """resume the specified instance."""
        xml = self._get_existing_domain_xml(instance, network_info,
                                            block_device_info)
        # NOTE(gsantos): The mediated devices that were removed on suspension
        # are still present in the xml. Let's take their references from it
        # and re-attach them.
        mdevs = self._get_mdevs_from_guest_config(xml)
        # NOTE(efried): The instance should already have a vtpm_secret_uuid
        # registered if appropriate.
        guest = self._create_guest_with_network(
            context, xml, instance, network_info, block_device_info,
            vifs_already_plugged=True)
        self._attach_pci_devices(guest,
            pci_manager.get_instance_pci_devs(instance))
        self._attach_direct_passthrough_ports(
            context, instance, guest, network_info)
        self._attach_mediated_devices(guest, mdevs)
        timer = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall(self._wait_for_running,
                                                     instance)
        timer.start(interval=0.5).wait()
        guest.sync_guest_time()

This pulls down the persistent domain XML and not the XML from the now virDomainManagedSave [1] domain that had the mdevs detached.

[1] https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainManagedSave

This eventually calls virDomainCreateWithFlags [1] against the domain and as noted there will restore the previously running state of the domain without the mdevs attached. That's causing the previous behaviour of things going AWOL now that hot-unplug isn't failing.

[1] https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainCreateWithFlags
So at this point the devices aren't actually attached to the running domain, they are however attached to the persistent domain that's just confusing the hell out of me.

Ah! This is being called with persistent=False and so libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_CONFIG is dropped from the request:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/4a359d576ddbc4b104116515c7e8b4176ac511f7/nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py#L424-L441

_detach_pci_devices is also making the same call here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/4a359d576ddbc4b104116515c7e8b4176ac511f7/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L4909

So that's why the devices are still found in the XML of the persistent domain when we try to resume.

Okay, so currently we try to not only hide hypervisor details from non-operator users, but also obscure the hypervisor details from users on different projects. We hash the project id with the hypervisor identification so that users on two separate projects can't compare hashes and determine that they are on the same (or different) hosts. That's good for privacy and preventing users from gaming the system, but it's bad because that's a one-way process and hard to reverse for the boot case.

I think what we're saying here is that if you're granted access to a set of hosts, and suitably endowed with permission to control boots targeted at those hosts, then exposing the "same or different host" details across projects is less of a concern because you're already allowed to control your own destiny within that subset of hosts to some degree. Is that right?

On the one hand, I think the cross-project obfuscation is a *really* nice feature for anyone that doesn't trust their users fully, but on the other, I know it's non-trivial to handle in two directions here.

yeah it is difficult to de-serialize in boot process but at least they will have one way to pass uuid for booting on host they are allowed.

Other thing i see, if any user want to boot server on special host and they are not allowed then they can ask operator to add them in access list.

Personally I don't think this is the best plan. First, it just means that existing people have to change the field they're using during boot if they're already passing a hostname. Second, we end up potentially confusing things if people use uuids for their hostnames. IIRC, ironic does (or did?) use the ironic uuid of a machine as the hypervisor_hostname.

My preference would be to _add_ a hypervisor_id field, and assert that it's mutually exclusive with hypervisor_hostname.

neutron/db/qos/models.py.message: AFAIK 'subquery' also eagerly loads, just for the whole result set at once. It's efficient for list requests (like when getting all FIPs for a router). 'joined' issues additional query for each object in the list, thus gives (N-1) more queries comparing to 'subquery'.

"subquery" is efficient when this parameter is not always used. When needed, we'll command a new SQL query to the DB. However this parameter is always used when the FIP OVO is created, to populate the new "qos_network_policy_id" parameter. "joined" will be faster because the "QosNetworkPolicyBinding" register will be retrieved in the same query.

I understand your concerns. But the reason I'm using "joined" is because the complexity added to the FIP query is minimal. What I'm adding is just two new fields (QosNetworkPolicyBinding fields) to this query with a comparison operator.

"subquery" will require two queries per FIP request.

In this case, same as with "Port" and "QosNetworkPolicyBinding", adding more complexity to a single query performs better than issuing two queries.
Sorry, maybe (N-1) more queries is not quite correct, just each fip query becomes more complex, while with 'subquery' allows to avoid it.

What you should do in the OVN mech driver is to capture the event [1]. If states[1] = {'fixed_ips': []}, that means we are removing all fixed_ips related to this port. If, as you check in your patch, this port belongs to a router and it's hosted by OVN, then is when you can raise the exception (before modifying any DB register, Neutron or OVN).

neutron/db/ipam_pluggable_backend.py.message: The IPAM module is backend agnostic. This issue affects only OVN. We should not fail here.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
I'm not sure if this approach is correct. This won't correctly update the OVN LRP register with the Neutron values.

If OVN does not accept having a LRP without networks, then we should raise an exception and prevent this operation.

What I'm trying to state here is that we always should have a perfect sync between the Neutron DB and OVN DB. This will break it.

You're correct, when you delete the last IP from the LRP the Neutron-DB deletes the entry on the `ipallocations` table, but since the write on the OVN-NB-DB network columns is incorrect, that value remains intact.

So even though this change would fix the incorrect OVN-NB-DB write, it would leave the two databases unsync.

I'll redo the patch in order to raise an exception.
At this point the Neutron DB port has been modified. We should not raise an exception here, leaving the Neutron DB and the OVN DB out of sync.

manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume/rbd.message: I am not sure I understood fully why we're always comparing with [0]?

Precisely. The "extra options" syntax will add the "var" variable to the "tripleo_ceph" section, and so the full list of extra options will place variables wherever the user wishes. If you have multiple backends, you can configure any variable you wish in any backend. In fact, you can leverage the "backend_defaults" section in cinder.conf if you want to apply a setting that affects all RBD backends in your deployment. For example, you could set the "backend_defaults:enable_deferred_deletion" option to True, and not worry about having to set the variable in each individual backend.

All of this helps explain why the $extra_options variable is "global," meaning it only needs to be handled once inside the loop.

The array is a list of all the backends. This check will only match one of the backend names, thereby ensuring $extra_options_real is set only once regardless of the number of backends in the array. And testing the [0] entry is safe, because that one exists even when there's just a single entry in the array (just one backend).
ok thanks, I understand it now ... I guess the format of extra_options (eg. tripleo_ceph/var) will eventually guarantee that "var" is applied for the "tripleo_ceph" backend only?
